Maybe from {{inh|ro|la|verbum||word}}<ref>CiorÄƒnescu, Alexandru (1966), "vorbÄƒ" in ''DicÈ›ionarul etimologic romÃ¢n'', San CristÃ³bal de La Laguna: University of La Laguna</ref> through ''*vÄƒrbu'', subsequently ''*vÄƒrbÄƒ'' by singularization of the supplanted neuter plural up to {{m|ro|vorbÄƒ}} in analogy to the change from [É™] to [o] in the imperative {{m|ro|vino}} from {{m|ro|vinÄƒ}}. The intermediate form ''*vÄƒrbu'' is strengthened by related Aromanian {{m|rup|vÃ£rghescu||to quarrel, scold, urge}}, having turned [b] into [g] which is a common trait. For instance, in the singular {{m|rup|corbu}} and in the plural {{m|rup|corghi}}.

Conversely, it might have come from {{bor|ro|sla-pro|*dvorÑŒba}}, from {{m|sla-pro|*dvorÑŠ||court}}, as sustained by the presupposed variant {{m|ro|horbÄƒ||gathering, word}}.<ref>CiorÄƒnescu, Alexandru (1966), "vorbÄƒ" in ''DicÈ›ionarul etimologic romÃ¢n'', San CristÃ³bal de La Laguna: University of La Laguna</ref> In the 17th century it still had the meaning of "gathering", attested by [[w:Dosoftei|Dosoftei BÄƒrilÄƒ]], but already by 1744, as attested by [[w:Ion Neculce|Ion Neculce]], it seems to have shifted to "word" in case this meaning was not already encompassed previously. Moreover, in old texts, a word {{m|ro|dvorbÄƒ}}, presumably of this etymology, meant "service to the court", and was never confused with {{m|ro||vorbÄƒ}}.<ref>CiorÄƒnescu, Alexandru (1966), "vorbÄƒ" in ''DicÈ›ionarul etimologic romÃ¢n'', San CristÃ³bal de La Laguna: University of La Laguna</ref>

From {{inh|sv|gmq-osw|trÃ¦et|trÇ£et}}, {{m|gmq-osw|trÃ¦t|trÇ£t}}, later {{m|gmq-osw|trÃ¦dh|trÇ£dh}}, originally the definite form of {{m|gmq-osw|trÃ¦|trÇ£|t=tree, wood}}, from {{inh|sv|non|trÃ©}}, from {{inh|sv|gem-pro|*trewÄ…|t=tree, wood}}, from pre-Germanic ''*drÃ©uÌ¯om'', thematic e-grade derivative of {{inh|sv|ine-pro|*dÃ³ru|gloss=tree}}. {{doublet|sv|trÃ¤}}. The form {{m|gmq-osw|trÃ¦dh}}, {{m|gmq-osw|trÃ¤dh}} was used still as the definite form in Old Swedish and in the {{w|Gustav Vasa Bible}} (1541), but by the early 18th century, it had split into the indefinite form meaning â€treeâ€, separate from {{m|sv|trÃ¤||wood}}. Hence, the modern definite form is {{m|sv||trÃ¤det}}, with the definite ending {{m|sv|-et}} on top of the now fossilized remnant of definite form ''-d''.

===Etymology===
{{inh+|enm|ang|trÄ“owÃ¾}}, {{m|ang|trÄ«ewÃ¾}}, from {{inh|enm|gmw-pro|*triuwiÃ¾u}}, from {{inh|enm|gem-pro|*triwwiÃ¾Å}}; euivalent to {{af|enm|trewe|-the|id2=abstract nominal|pos2=abstract nominal suffix}}. 

The final vowel is generalised from Old English oblique cases, while forms in {{IPAchar|/iuÌ¯/}} reflect the influence of {{m|en|trewe}}; the usual vocalism in {{IPAchar|/É›uÌ¯/|/É”uÌ¯/}} is due to shortening before the consonant cluster {{IPAchar|/wÎ¸/}} in late Old English.
